page.title: 07Grantham:Water works
page.content: The Anglian Water Authority controls the small reservoir and water works at Saltersford on the River Witham. These water works were established in the 19th Century to provide Grantham with water when the town wells and the medieval Conduit became inadequate.By coincidence the site was found to contain an extensive Romano-British river ford settlement. This was the crossing of the River Witham originally known as the Salters Ford after the road used in pre-Medieval times for the transport of salt. Excavations around 1900 by Henry Preston,the manager of the waterworks, revealed many find relating to everyday Romano-British life which are now in the Grantham Museum.
